item.title: Prehistoric Patterns in Python
item.description:
Description

Why do some code use dictionaries that have None for all values? Is it true that you shouldn't concatenate strings with +? Will Python optimize constant calculations?

This talk will go through some patterns that used to be common in Python, but which now are regarded as outdated and see if they really are outdated and why. The results surprised me, maybe they'll surprise you.
item.dc:creator: Lennart Regebro

item.title: An introduction to reporting databases
item.description:
Description

This talk explains what a reporting database is, and why, when and how you should use it.
item.dc:creator: Lennart Regebro

item.title: Your keyboard
item.description:
Description

As a programmer, your fingers and the keyboard is the interface between your brain and the computer, and is one of your most important work tools. Yet is it often overlooked, and people tend to just use whatever keyboard that came with the computer. This talk will take an in-depth look at your computer keyboard.
item.dc:creator: Lennart Regebro

item.title: Who's afraid of the Big Bad 3?
item.description:
Description

Tytuł/Topic: Who's afraid of the Big Bad 3? Prelegent/Speaker: Lennart Regebro

Python 3 is often described in scary words, with claims like it being another language and that is is tearing the community in two etc. If you believe what some people are saying, it's slow, it's a nightmare, porting is a pain and you are gonna get eaten alive! The truth is much less frightening, and this talk will take a high level perspective of Python 3, and look at my and others experience with supporting it and tell you how you can switch to Python 3.

http://pl.pycon.org/2014/pl/agenda
item.dc:creator: Lennart Regebro

item.title: Prehistoric Python Patterns
item.description:
Description

Tytuł/Topic: Prehistoric Python Patterns Prelegent/Speaker: Lennart Regebro

There are many idioms and patterns that used to be a best practice but isn't anymore, thanks to changes in Python. Despite that they often show up even in new code, and some of these patterns are even explained to be Good Ideas at stackoverflow and similar. This talk will bring out the most common of these patterns so you know what they are, and why you should avoid them.

http://pl.pycon.org/2013/pl/agenda
item.dc:creator: Lennart Regebro

item.title: DjangoCon EU 2013: Lennart Regebro - Prehistorical Python: Patterns past their prime
item.description:
Description

Videos from DjangoCon Europe 2013 are kindly provided by Heroku, a cloud application platform -- a new way of building and deploying web apps: http://heroku.com/
item.dc:creator: Lennart Regebro

item.title: Blame it on Caesar: What you need to know about dates, times and time zones
item.description:
Summary

Time measurement is a complex area full of tricky problems and unexpected edge-cases. This fast-paced talk tells you how to avoid the pitfalls, and warn about the compromises.
item.dc:creator: Lennart Regebro
